name: Verb
definition: A verb is a word that shows action, state, or occurrence. It tells us what someone or something is doing, feeling, or being.
importance: Verbs are the heart of every sentence. Without a verb, you don't have a complete sentence. Verbs express what's happening, what will happen, or what happened.
tagline: Show action, express state, tell the story!

types.name: Action Verbs
types.description: Verbs that show physical or mental action. They describe what the subject is doing.

types.name: Linking Verbs
types.description: Verbs that connect the subject to a subject complement. They don't show action but show a state or condition.

types.name: Helping Verbs (Auxiliary Verbs)
types.description: Verbs that work with main verbs to form different tenses and moods. They help create verb phrases.

types.name: Modal Verbs
types.description: Special verbs that show possibility, necessity, permission, or ability. They always come before the main verb.

rules.title: DO: Use Correct Verb Tense
points: Use present tense for actions happening now: 'I eat breakfast every morning.'
Use past tense for actions that already happened: 'I ate breakfast this morning.'
Use future tense for actions that will happen: 'I will eat breakfast tomorrow.'
examples: ‚úÖ We will travel next month. (Future simple)

rules.title: DO: Agree Verb with Subject
points: Singular subjects take singular verbs: 'The dog runs fast.'
Plural subjects take plural verbs: 'The dogs run fast.'
Third person singular adds '-s' or '-es': 'He walks', 'She watches'

rules.title: DO: Use Active Voice When Possible
points: Active voice is clearer and more direct: subject performs the action
Use: 'The cat caught the mouse' instead of 'The mouse was caught by the cat'
Active voice is stronger and more engaging

rules.title: DON'T: Mix Verb Tenses Incorrectly
points: Don't switch tenses without reason: 'He runs to the store and bought milk' (inconsistent)
Keep verb tenses consistent in a paragraph unless time changes
If the timeline changes, signal it clearly
examples: ‚ùå She walks to school and took the bus home. ‚Üí ‚úÖ She walked to school and took the bus home.
‚ùå I am going and I will come back. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I am going and I will come back. (Clear time difference)
‚ùå They play football and cooked dinner. ‚Üí ‚úÖ They played football and cooked dinner.

rules.title: DON'T: Use Wrong Verb Form
points: Don't use base form when you need past: 'I go yesterday' (wrong)
Don't forget the '-ed' ending for regular past tense: 'She walk' (should be 'walked')
Learn irregular verbs: go‚Üíwent, eat‚Üíate, run‚Üíran, not 'goed', 'eated', 'runned'
examples: ‚ùå I see him yesterday. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I saw him yesterday.
‚ùå She don't like pizza. ‚Üí ‚úÖ She doesn't like pizza.
‚ùå He go to school every day. ‚Üí ‚úÖ He goes to school every day.

They have been studying for the exam.

exercises.title: Write Sentences with Correct Verb Forms
exercises.prompt:
Write 5 sentences using different verb types:
1. An action verb in present simple
2. A linking verb in past tense
3. A helping verb with a main verb
4. A modal verb
5. An action verb in future tense
exercises.sample_answer:
1. The students discuss the homework in class. (Action, present)
2. The food was delicious. (Linking, past)
3. I have completed the project. (Helping, present perfect)
4. You should study harder for the test. (Modal)
5. We will travel to Paris next summer. (Future)

exercises.title: Correct Verb Tense and Form Errors
exercises.passage: Yesterday, I go to the store and I buys milk. The store manager is very helpful and he tells me about a sale. I decide to buying vegetables too. While I am paying, he says that the vegetables is fresh. I thank him and I leaves the store. When I arrives home, I puts the groceries away. My family are very happy because we will has fresh vegetables for dinner.
exercises.sample_answer: Yesterday, I went to the store and bought milk. The store manager was very helpful and told me about a sale. I decided to buy vegetables too. While I was paying, he said the vegetables were fresh. I thanked him and left the store. When I arrived home, I put the groceries away. My family was very happy because we would have fresh vegetables for dinner.

common_mistakes.error: She go to school every day.
common_mistakes.correct: She goes to school every day.
common_mistakes.explanation: Third person singular subject needs an 's' on the verb. 'Goes' is correct, not 'go'.
Third person singular uses 'doesn't', not 'don't'. The negative form must agree with the subject.

common_mistakes.error: I will go and I come back.
common_mistakes.correct: I will go and come back. (Or: I will go and I will come back.)
common_mistakes.explanation: Avoid unnecessary verb repetition. You can use one future marker for related actions.
In American English, collective nouns like 'team' take singular verbs. (British English allows 'are')

common_mistakes.correct: I have gone there before. (Or: I went there before.)
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Have' requires the past participle 'gone', not the simple past 'went'.

common_mistakes.error: She can goes to the party.
common_mistakes.correct: She can go to the party.
common_mistakes.explanation: Modal verbs like 'can' are followed by the base form of the verb, not the third person form.

common_mistakes.error: They was excited about the trip.
common_mistakes.correct: They were excited about the trip.
common_mistakes.explanation: Plural subjects use 'were', not 'was'. 'They' is plural, so it requires 'were'.

common_mistakes.error: The students is working on their projects.
common_mistakes.correct: The students are working on their projects.
common_mistakes.explanation: Plural subject 'students' requires plural verb 'are', not singular 'is'.

quick_facts: Every sentence needs at least one verb to be complete.
English has three main tenses: present, past, and future.
Regular verbs add '-ed' for past tense; irregular verbs change form (go‚Üíwent, eat‚Üíate).
There are 23 modal verbs in English, all showing ability, possibility, or obligation.
Linking verbs don't show action; they connect subjects to descriptions.
Helping verbs work with main verbs to create different meanings and tenses.
Most English verbs are regular (add -ed for past), but common ones are often irregular.
The verb 'be' is the most irregular and most common verb in English.
